text: English vocabulary lesson 16 there are a
number of expressions in English about
bridges I thought this was a pretty good
place to share three of them with you
[Music]
the first expression is water under the
bridge water under the bridge usually
refers to an unpleasant experience or
event that's in the past because it's in
the past we can't change it and it's no
longer considered importance in the
present example when the two sisters
were teenagers they fought over
boyfriends that's water under the bridge
now they're both happily married and
they consider each other best friends
the second expression is burned bridges
to burn bridges is to leave a situation
in such a way that you can never go back
or it's to leave a relationship with one
person or a group of people in such a
way that you'll never be welcome again
example if you plan to quit your job
don't burn bridges be professional and
respectful when you make your
announcement who knows one day you may
need to ask for your old job back
our last expression is cross that bridge
when you come to it to cross that bridge
when you come to it means to deal with a
problem when it happens you can't cross
a bridge until you're actually there
so one worry about possible problems
deal with a problem when it actually
happened example don't worry about
paying tuition right now you can cross
that bridge when you come to it just
focus on getting into a good university
let's review our three expressions
[Music]
what's the expression an unpleasant
experience or event that is in the past
and no longer important in the present
do you remember water under the bridge
note how we use it we often say that's
water under the bridge or it's water
under the bridge
what's the expression to leave a
situation or relationship in such a way
that it's not possible to return do you
remember
burning bridges we often say don't burn
your bridges or don't burn any bridges
what's the expression to be concerned
about or to deal with the problem only
when it happens and not before
do you remember cross that bridge when
you come to it
here are some common ways we use the
expression let's cross that bridge when
we come to it let's not cross that
bridge until we come to it don't cross
that bridge until you come to it let's
try an exercise exercise 1 choose the
correct expression to complete each
statement statement 1 read it to
yourself and then I'll tell you the
answer answer I know you're worried
about the reaction Wendy's parents will
have to the idea of your marriage but
don't cross that bridge until you come
to it first you have to ask Wendy to
marry you
statement 2 again read it to yourself
and then I'll tell you the answer answer
the two co-workers argued in the past
but that's water under the bridge
they've learned to be respectful and
even supportive of each other's work
statement 3
answer the agent told the actress not to
burn bridges the actress took this
advice and apologized to the film
director for criticizing his work and
not cooperating let's try one more
exercise exercise to answer the
questions if you're studying by yourself
write down your answers if you're
studying with a partner take turns
asking the questions question 1
have you burned any bridges that you now
have regrets about
question two is it easy for you to
forgive a wrongdoing and call it water
under the bridge or do you stay angry
for a long time
question 3 do you cross the bridge only
when you come to it or do you often
worry before a problem actually happens
additional practice for this lesson can
be found at English canva.com
my user name is Jennifer ESL follow the
direct link listed in the video
description well that's all for now
thanks for watching and happy studies
